HENRY EVANS ELECTED EDITOR

Will Take Charge of News-Letter Upon
Return from France in November.

for Call—'15 Men May Leave for

At a meeting of THE NEWSLETTER Board last Monday, the
resignation of Reuben Oppenheimer, as editor-in-chief was accepted,
and Henry C. Evans was elected
in his place. Immediately after
the election, a motion was passed
giving Evans leave of absence until his return from France, where
he is going to serve in the American Ambulance Corps, and Mitchell B. Carroll was elected to serve
as managing editor until his return.
The new editor is a member of
the Junior Class and has been an
associate editor of THE NEWSLETTER for two years. Throughout the whole of the past season,
he has acted as assistant to the
editor and has showed himself
eminently capable of directing
THE NEWS-LETTER'S destinies.
Evans came to Hopkins from
the Baltimore City College, where
he won the first Peabody prize of
one hundred dollars. While at
Hopkins, he has taken a prominent part in public speaking activities, having been a member of
the junior team in the recent interclass debate and having been
chosen to repres'ent Hopkins in
the oratorical contest with other
colleges of Maryland and the District of Columbia, which was to
have taken place on March 28.
Evans was one of the new members initiated last week into the
Omicron Delta Kappa Society. Inasmuch as his period of enlistment in the ambulance corps
is only for six months, the new
editor will probably take active
charge Of THE NEWS-LETTER early
in November.
Mitchell B. Carroll, the managing editor, is a member of the
Sophomore Class. He was elected
to THE NEWS-LETTER Board in his
freshman year, and, like Evans,
has helped in the making up of
the paper throughout the past
season.
During the early part of next
year THE NEWS-LETTER will be
able to offer an exceptionally interesting feature—a series of articles, written by its editor, describing the action upon the French
front. The articles will necessarily be so limited in their content
as to be able to pass the censor.
but in all probabilty enough material will be available for publicai
tion to make the series a noteworthy one in college journalism.

About 100 Johns Hopkins physicians and surgeons of the necessary qualifications have volunteered for service under the American flag in France. Although, for
obvious reasons, no definite information is being given out at the
hospital, it is practically certain
that at least fifteen of the number
will be among the very first to
leave .for the front. Several of
these men have already left, and
it is reported that the remainder
are rapidly preparing for departure.
In view of the policy of the
Government of a speedy reinforcement of the hospital forces of the
Allies by American units, it is
considered very nrobable that
many more of the Johns Hopkins
men who have applied will be
called to active service in a short
time. The calls for duty come at
short notice, so that it is impossible to predict the time or order
of the departure of the applicants.
Johns Hopkins is, however, certain to furnish a large share of
the quota of 300 physicians and
surgeons which Maryland will be
asked to furnish. The men who
leave now wilr serve at clearinghouses for the wounded, about 10
or 15 miles behind the battle-front.
In addition to the regularly
qualified volunteers, many of- the
third and fourth year students of
the Medical School expect to serve
in different capacities at the front
during the coming summer. A
few have already left the city.
This activity is entirely distinct
from the Johns Hopkins base hospital unit. Under the direction
of Dr. Winford Smith, of the hospital, the work of organizing and
equipping the latter is going on
steadily, and assurance is given
that it will be thoroughly fitted
for efficient service.

Members of the Hopkins faculty are to become farmers during
the summer months, and their
farms are to be parts of the University grounds.
In response to the urgent appeal of the Government that
every available agricultural site
be utilized, the Board of Trustees
have granted permission for the
tilling of a large portion of the
Homewood grounds, under the direction of faculty volunteers.
The portion of the University's
grounds facing on the boulevard
to the rear of the Carroll Mansion is to be utilized for this purpose. The sod has already been
broken and cultivation is to be
begun immediately. The farm is
also to be utilized in the work of
several departments of the Hopkins summer school.
In addition to the action of the
faculty members, a movement is
on foot to form a battalion of
"The Farm Army" among the students of the University. One or
two men have already left to
work on farms, and quite a number of others have signified their
willingness and intention to do
so if the necessary arrangements
can be made.
The men who go to serve their
country in this way will be given
the same privileges by the University as those who have joined
some branch of the military or
naval forces. That is, they will
be given credit for the full
amount of this year's work, provided that, upon their return to
the University next fall, or whenever it may be, their average for
their first term is over six. This
regulktion naturally applies only
to those students whose marks
are at the present time up to
the passing grade.
The Department of Agriculture
at Washington has stated that
there is a vital need for individual co-operation in solving the
food problem which confronts the
nation. This need has been expressed by Herbert C. Hoover,
chairman of the American Commission. for Relief of Belgium,
who has just been appointed head
of the American Food Board, in
the following words:
"I feel it my duty to emphasize that the food situation is one
of the utmost gravity, which, unless it is solved, may possibly result in the collapse of everything
we hold dear in civilization.

During the course of next week,
twenty Hopkins students or more
will leave for the Reserve Officers'
training camp at Fort Myer, Va.
The four captains of the Hopkins
battalion—J. T. Thompson, J. W.
Darley, C. W. Chesley and W. B.
Baxley—Harry L. Straus, captain
of this year's track team, and
Corporal R. W. Evitt of the
corps, who took the examinations
before the War Department's recent announcement, will be given
their commissions before their departure.
Those who have passed the physical examination and have sent
in their applications to attend the
camp are waiting for their notifications of acceptance, which will
probably arrive on May 9, the
selections being made on May 8.
The men are Lieutenants E. G.
Hall, H. S. Baker and A. S. McCabe of the battalion, J. G. Rouse,
J. M. Mowbray, E. L. Warner,
sergeant bugler of the battalion;
A. C. Davis, K. S. Cullom, C. C.
Beetham, E. M. Stuart, J. Knipp,
C. W. Heisse, C. K. Krantz and
Shaw. A. Barton, Prevost Boyce
and M. E. Bagley, graduates of
Hopkins, also expect to go.
On last Saturday; Lieutenant
Robert France of the corps and
Henry C. Evans sailed on the
French liner Essene for Havre,
France, whence they will proceed
to Paris to be instructed in theii
duties as ambulance drivers in
the American Ambulance Field
Service. They are in a party of
forty Americans, most of them
being students from other eastern
colleges. One of the number is
Leslie Buckler, of Baltimore, a
graduate of Hopkins in 1912.
Simon Klosky, graduate student in chemistry, sailed on Monday for Newport News, Va., where
he is to study aeronautics and
learn to fly. Hopkins has also another man in the Aviation Corps
—Leonard Bruton, who entered
Hopkins with the present gradu- .
ating class, but left to attend the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is reported to be making efficient progress at Pensacola,
Fla.
In all probability Lieutenant
Elliott, who is to be made a captain in July, will be stationed at
the fort, as will possibly First
Sergeant Friedlander, who has
just been notified that his application for a commission in the Officers' Reserve Corps has been accepted.

will bring in its active staff, THE
NEWS-LETTER wishes to announce

The Hopkins battalion is to see
some real practical training this
week in the way of digging
trenches. This is made possible
by the fact that Lieutenant Elliott has been -temporarily relieved
from his duties as examining officer of applicants for the Reserve
Officers' Training Camp at Fort
Myer. From now on he will be
actively engaged in initiating the
corps into the intricate science of
war.
The scene of the entrenchment
will be the edge of,the woods facing south of the Civil and Mechanical Engineering Building.
The University has provided the
necessary tools—picks and shovels—and the work will be under
the direct supervision of First
Sergeant Evans, retired, United
States Engineer Corps.
A one Company standing trench
will be dug first, the excavation
being carried on in turn by the
companies—one wielding the implements while the other three
drill.
With the departure of Captains
Thompson, Darley, Chesley and
Baxley, Lieutenants E. G. Hall,
Robert France, H. S. Baker and
A. •S. McCabe, and several noncommissioned officers of the corps,
a large number of promotions will
be in order this week, which, says
Lieutenant Elliott, will be based
largely on attendance.
The question of attendance is
one which has required the attention of the dean, as well as Lieutenant Elliott. At times recently as many as sixty men have been
absent at one drill. Since it was
impossible to have efficient drills
with such grossly depleted ranks,
Lieutenant Elliott, in consideration of the prevailing sentiment
that the drills every day precluded sufficient preparation of
studies — the supposed cause of
many absences—reduced the drills
to three a week. Moreover, the
rule was put into effect last week
that should a student fail to make
up an absence from drill on the
first opportunity offered, he will
be suspended from the University
until it is made up or a plausible
excuse is presented.
If the drills this week have the
normal attendance, Lieutenant Elliott is going to have the members
of the corps vote on whether they
want drills every day or only
three days a week. It has been
pointed out that several colleges
—Cornell, Harvard and Princeton
—hold drills lasting from six to
eight hours every day, and though
such a plan as this is not advocated at Hopkins, it is anticipated by many that the vote will
restore the daily drills.

There will come a time when the
historians at their desks will arrange their materials neatly before them, ponder a while in their
arm-chairs, and then carefully and
accurately trace the trend of the
world in the second decade of the
twentieth century. Perhaps in one
of their text-books will appear
some such sentence as this: "Nowhere was the depth of the fervor
with which the United States entered the Great War evidenced
more clearly than in the colleges
and universities; throughout the
country, students offered themselves to the Government with an
enthusiasm which could leave no
doubt as to- the intellectual and
spiritual sympathy which the nation's thinking men had come to
feel for the cause of the Allies"—
and then the book will pass on to
point out the development of nationalism, or the cause of the
change of ministry in England.
In such phrases as these will our
reaction to the war be dismissed;
we will be part of the past, the
class which we represent but a
tiny thread in the great tapestry.
And yet, by that reaction, the future is to be made; as we, rudely
aroused from the smugness of our
petty round, seek and seek with-

in ourselves the cause and the
,goal, we represent, not one small
class of men, but the intellectual
forces of the world.
Already the throbbing exhilaration is gone; more and more, as
our time comes, the stark reality
of wholesale butchery will be
thrust before our eyes. Believing,
with all our hearts and souls, in
the brotherhood of man, we will
see our nation throwing all its
tremendous resources into the development of the technique of killing; we will see great guns systematically mowing down hundreds and thousands of men not
one whit different from ourselves;
our own hands may be red with
the blood of those whom our bayonets have pierced—and then, when
the horror of it becomes almost
unbearable, when the world is but
a howling pit of lust, before our
eyes will flash the one word Democracy—and we will go on in
the fight knowing, as we know today, that our fight is holy.
All things else are immaterial.
Isms have gone, finely shaded theories of life, personal ambitions—
these things are all become infinitely trivial. Shoulder to shoulder
with the men of France and England and Russia we have embarked upon the last crusade; the
spark kindled in 1789 is sweeping
over the world—from our united
ranks there rises a single cry, and
by the might of that cry the promise of the centuries shall be realized.
How many millions of us die
upon the battlefield, in a generation, will no longer matter. If
the thing for which we strive shall
have been achieved, we shall not
have died in vain, but, by our
death, shall have left the greatest
heritage to the future which one
generation ever left to another.
Days of work deadly grim lie before us; but the grimness is transfigured by the light of the banner
which we flaunt. We make war
not that a -nation may be crushed,
but that it may see that light.
With the banner of democracy
above us, there can be no defeat—
for it is the banner of mankind.
Hopkins Alumnus Marries.

Mr. George P. Thomas, who
graduated from Hopkins with the
Class of 1912, was recently married to Miss Elizabeth Randolph
Turner. One of the ushers was
Mr. Leslie Buckler,'12, who sailed
last Saturday with R. France and
H. Evans to serve in the American Ambulance Corps in France.

At Other Colleges in War-time.
Twenty men from the University of Pittsburgh have en.listed in
various branches of the Government service. The University is
conducting daily drills with an
attendance of 700.
* * * The entire Senior Class at Lehigh University wished to enlist
upon the declaration of war, but
was shown by the faculty that
such a course would not be to the
best interests of the country.
* * *
At the University of Wisconsin,
where between 1,200 and 1,300
young men are being trained for
service as officers or privates, commencement was held on May 1, in
order that the rest of the school
year may be given up to training
the men in military tactics and
the women in Red Cross work.
* * *
Thirty Cornell undergraduates,
members of the newly organized
unit of the American Ambulance
Corps have sailed for active duty
in field service on the French
front.
* *
•
Approximately 2,000 students
have registered for the military
training course to be begun immediately at the University of
Texas. Fourteen full companies
are to be formed.
* * *
_
Plans have been completed for
the erection and maintenance of
a 500-bed war hospital unit to be
erected on the Columbia Oval. It
can be completed in 90 days if
funds are forthcoming, and will
be used for Red Cross training, as
well as for war service. The cost
of erecting this hospital and maintaining it for one year has been
estimated at $700,000.
* * *
President Garfield, of Williams
College, has announced that, according to the decision of the faculty, students will be permitted
to drop two courses and receive
full credit for the semester if
their military work is completed
satisfactorily. More than 80 per
cent, of the college body have
joined the Williams battalion of
the Reserve Officers' Training
Corps. Drills are now taking
place every afternoon.
* * *
Nineteen members of Harvard
University have signed up for
American ambulance field service
in France and are scheduled to
sail shortly.
*
*
Twenty-two colleges were represented by nearly 10,000 student
soldiers in the "Wake Up America" parade in New York on April
19.
* • *
Seventeen seniors of the George
Washington University Medical

School have taken their final examinations and will soon be commissioned as assistant surgeons in
the United States Navy.
* * *
Forty-five members of the University of Washington faculty are
drilling daily. Several members
of the faculty are taking a course
in military topography.

The first lecture under the
Percy Turnbull Memorial Leetures on Poetry Foundation was
given on Monday, April 30, in the
lecture-room of the Civil Engineering Building by Edward
Capps, Ph. D., LL. D., professor
of the Classics in Princeton University.
Other lectures were
given on Wednesday and Friday
afternoons. The subject for Dr.
Capps' series is "Formative Influences in Greek Tragedy."
The lecture on Monday afternoon was an introduction to the
series. Dr. Capps told of the different Greek plays about which
he was going to talk and of the
period which these plays embraced. The subject for Dr.
Capps' lecture on Wednesday was
"The Primitive Theatre."
•"The primitive theatre," said
Dr. Capps, "would hardly be recognized as a theatre by any of us
who have seen the present-day
theatres, with their beautiful
scenery and wonderful lighting
effects. The theatre in Greece had
only one scene and this had to
stay up all of the time, regardless
of whether it was appropriate or
not for the supposedly depicted
scene."
In the third lecture, on Friday,
the subject of which was "Change
and Experiment," Dr. Capps described the improvements that
were added to the theatre. "There
were five stages in the development of the Greek tragedy," he
said. "The primitive theatre consisted of a chorus and a chorus
leader and the five stages that
brought it to its later development
were: first, the introduction of
the first actor; second, the introduction of the second actor by
Aeschylus; third, the introduction of the third actor by Sophocles ; fourth, the invention of the
back scene; and, fifth, the gradual
change from simplicity to seriousness and grandeur."
Dr.Capps then showed how that
with only three speaking actors
allowed in any play it was always
necessary for the actors to play
more than one part.
"In one play," Dr. Capps declared, "the same actor was obliged to take the parts of a beautiful slim girl and a swarthy
blacksmith. In another it was
necessary for a messenger to bring
a letter on the stage telling of the
death of the hero, and the part of
the messenger had to be taken by
the same actor who had previously
taken the part of the hero." .
Three more lectures are to be
given this week—one each on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. -

will be among the very first to
leave .for the front. Several of
these men have already left, and
it is reported that the remainder
are rapidly preparing for departure.
In view of the policy of the
Government of a speedy reinforcement of the hospital forces of the
Allies by American units, it is
considered very nrobable that
many more of the Johns Hopkins
men who have applied will be
called to active service in a short
time. The calls for duty come at
short notice, so that it is impossible to predict the time or order
of the departure of the applicants.
Johns Hopkins is, however, certain to furnish a large share of
the quota of 300 physicians and
surgeons which Maryland will be
asked to furnish. The men who
leave now wilr serve at clearinghouses for the wounded, about 10

In addition to the regularly
qualified volunteers, many of- the
third and fourth year students of
the Medical School expect to serve
in different capacities at the front
during the coming summer. A
few have already left the city.
This activity is entirely distinct
from the Johns Hopkins base hospital unit. Under the direction
of Dr. Winford Smith, of the hospital, the work of organizing and
equipping the latter is going on
steadily, and assurance is given
that it will be thoroughly fitted
for efficient service.

Members of the Hopkins faculty are to become farmers during
the summer months, and their
farms are to be parts of the University grounds.

every available agricultural site
be utilized, the Board of Trustees
have granted permission for the
tilling of a large portion of the
Homewood grounds, under the direction of faculty volunteers.

grounds facing on the boulevard

begun immediately. The farm is

regulktion naturally applies only

The Hopkins battalion is to see
some real practical training this
week in the way of digging
trenches. This is made possible
by the fact that Lieutenant Elliott has been -temporarily relieved
from his duties as examining officer of applicants for the Reserve
Officers' Training Camp at Fort
Myer. From now on he will be
actively engaged in initiating the
corps into the intricate science of
war.
The scene of the entrenchment
will be the edge of,the woods facing south of the Civil and Mechanical Engineering Building.
The University has provided the
necessary tools—picks and shovels—and the work will be under
the direct supervision of First
Sergeant Evans, retired, United

A one Company standing trench
will be dug first, the excavation

companies—one wielding the implements while the other three

one which has required the attention of the dean, as well as Lieutenant Elliott. At times recently as many as sixty men have been
absent at one drill. Since it was
impossible to have efficient drills
with such grossly depleted ranks,

that the drills every day precluded sufficient preparation of
studies — the supposed cause of
many absences—reduced the drills

rule was put into effect last week

up an absence from drill on the
first opportunity offered, he will
be suspended from the University
until it is made up or a plausible
excuse is presented.

normal attendance, Lieutenant Elliott is going to have the members

want drills every day or only
three days a week. It has been
pointed out that several colleges
—Cornell, Harvard and Princeton

eight hours every day, and though
such a plan as this is not advocated at Hopkins, it is anticipated by many that the vote will
restore the daily drills.

There will come a time when the
historians at their desks will arrange their materials neatly before them, ponder a while in their
arm-chairs, and then carefully and
accurately trace the trend of the
world in the second decade of the
twentieth century. Perhaps in one
of their text-books will appear
some such sentence as this: "Nowhere was the depth of the fervor
with which the United States entered the Great War evidenced
more clearly than in the colleges
and universities; throughout the
country, students offered themselves to the Government with an
enthusiasm which could leave no
doubt as to- the intellectual and
spiritual sympathy which the nation's thinking men had come to
feel for the cause of the Allies"—
and then the book will pass on to
point out the development of nationalism, or the cause of the
change of ministry in England.
In such phrases as these will our
reaction to the war be dismissed;
we will be part of the past, the
class which we represent but a
tiny thread in the great tapestry.
And yet, by that reaction, the future is to be made; as we, rudely
aroused from the smugness of our
petty round, seek and seek with-

in ourselves the cause and the
,goal, we represent, not one small
class of men, but the intellectual
forces of the world.
Already the throbbing exhilaration is gone; more and more, as
our time comes, the stark reality
of wholesale butchery will be
thrust before our eyes. Believing,
with all our hearts and souls, in
the brotherhood of man, we will
see our nation throwing all its
tremendous resources into the development of the technique of killing; we will see great guns systematically mowing down hundreds and thousands of men not
one whit different from ourselves;
our own hands may be red with
the blood of those whom our bayonets have pierced—and then, when
the horror of it becomes almost
unbearable, when the world is but
a howling pit of lust, before our
eyes will flash the one word Democracy—and we will go on in
the fight knowing, as we know today, that our fight is holy.
All things else are immaterial.
Isms have gone, finely shaded theories of life, personal ambitions—
these things are all become infinitely trivial. Shoulder to shoulder
with the men of France and England and Russia we have embarked upon the last crusade; the
spark kindled in 1789 is sweeping
over the world—from our united
ranks there rises a single cry, and
by the might of that cry the promise of the centuries shall be realized.
How many millions of us die
upon the battlefield, in a generation, will no longer matter. If
the thing for which we strive shall
have been achieved, we shall not
have died in vain, but, by our
death, shall have left the greatest
heritage to the future which one
generation ever left to another.
Days of work deadly grim lie before us; but the grimness is transfigured by the light of the banner
which we flaunt. We make war
not that a -nation may be crushed,
but that it may see that light.
With the banner of democracy
above us, there can be no defeat—
for it is the banner of mankind.

The first lecture under the
Percy Turnbull Memorial Leetures on Poetry Foundation was
given on Monday, April 30, in the
lecture-room of the Civil Engineering Building by Edward
Capps, Ph. D., LL. D., professor
of the Classics in Princeton University.
Other lectures were
given on Wednesday and Friday
afternoons. The subject for Dr.
Capps' series is "Formative Influences in Greek Tragedy."
The lecture on Monday afternoon was an introduction to the
series. Dr. Capps told of the different Greek plays about which
he was going to talk and of the
period which these plays embraced. The subject for Dr.
Capps' lecture on Wednesday was
"The Primitive Theatre."
•"The primitive theatre," said
Dr. Capps, "would hardly be recognized as a theatre by any of us
who have seen the present-day
theatres, with their beautiful
scenery and wonderful lighting
effects. The theatre in Greece had
only one scene and this had to
stay up all of the time, regardless
of whether it was appropriate or
not for the supposedly depicted
scene."
In the third lecture, on Friday,
the subject of which was "Change
and Experiment," Dr. Capps described the improvements that
were added to the theatre. "There
were five stages in the development of the Greek tragedy," he
said. "The primitive theatre consisted of a chorus and a chorus
leader and the five stages that
brought it to its later development
were: first, the introduction of
the first actor; second, the introduction of the second actor by
Aeschylus; third, the introduction of the third actor by Sophocles ; fourth, the invention of the
back scene; and, fifth, the gradual
change from simplicity to seriousness and grandeur."
Dr.Capps then showed how that
with only three speaking actors
allowed in any play it was always
necessary for the actors to play
more than one part.
"In one play," Dr. Capps declared, "the same actor was obliged to take the parts of a beautiful slim girl and a swarthy
blacksmith. In another it was
necessary for a messenger to bring
a letter on the stage telling of the
death of the hero, and the part of
the messenger had to be taken by
the same actor who had previously
taken the part of the hero." .
Three more lectures are to be
given this week—one each on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. -
